name: Flow Alteration (Regulation / Water Use)
functionStatement:
Streamflow regime integrates the range of flows experienced by other processes and supports channel form, habitat diversity, and ecological life-cycle cues.
"Integrates the range of ""typical"" flows experienced by other processes. Examines the degree to which upstream infrastructure or land uses have fundamentally altered flow regimes (e.g., hydropeaking, dams, withdrawals)."
descriptionMarkdown:
Degree of alteration in flow magnitude, timing, duration, or permanence relative to natural conditions due to regulation, withdrawals/returns, or watershed change.
Compares current daily-flow pattern to the natural regime, combining IHA metrics with the Richards-Baker flashiness index to screen for alteration from dams, withdrawals, or urbanization.
methodContextMarkdown:
Context: Channel

Method: Desktop (gage/records) with field verification where feasible; Desktop
howToMeasureMarkdown:
Use available flow records (gage data), modeled natural baseline estimates, and/or water-use/rights information to estimate change from expected natural conditions for the metric definition. Assign the condition class using the bin thresholds for this metric.
Compare current mean annual flow to a natural or historical baseline and report percent difference.

levels.label: Optimal
levels.criteriaMarkdown: Good: <10% difference from baseline. (Suggested index range 0.70-1.0)

levels.label: Poor
levels.criteriaMarkdown: Poor: >50% difference. Near dewatering or strong hydropeaking. (Suggested index range 0.0-0.29)
